dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so the three W-approach—When, Why, and Who—is apparently the key to a perfect checklist, but only if you use it to, uh, not actually complete anything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so the three W-approach-When, Why, and Who-is apparently the key to a perfect checklist, but only if you use it to, uh, not actually complete anything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and according to this, you should absolutely never inform anyone, especially investors, that the project is finished. Like, keep them totally in the dark until the last possible moment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and according to this, you should absolutely never inform anyone, especially investors, that the project is finished. Like, keep them totally in the dark until the last possible moment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Because who doesn't want an angry investor showing up completely unaware that you've technically ignored all contractual obligations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Because who doesn't want an angry investor showing up completely unaware that you've technically ignored all contractual obligations?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the communication strategy—make sure your message gets lost among other press releases and presentations. Stone Age style, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the communication strategy-make sure your message gets lost among other press releases and presentations. Stone Age style, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the information century, it is essential that your message about your project and your projects product(s) dont get lost among other messages, press releases and presentations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, don't even bother choosing tools that might actually reach stakeholders. Just hope nobody finds out you succeeded.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, don't even bother choosing tools that might actually reach stakeholders. Just hope nobody finds out you succeeded.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, you should choose your communication strategy and communication tools wisely so that more people, potential stakeholders and investors and especially your friends and colleagues know about the successful completion of the project and delivered results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And when it comes to B2B reporting, effective managers should personally hide their achievements in private events. No sharing with partners or clients!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And when it comes to B2B reporting, effective managers should personally hide their achievements in private events. No sharing with partners or clients!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective project managers always personally present the main achievements of their completed project to all their current and potential partners and clients in a public event or even a series of public events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is funny because it says traditional B2B presentations are paradoxically in fashion, but you still shouldn't calibrate the scope or depth. Just wing it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is funny because it says traditional B2B presentations are paradoxically in fashion, but you still shouldn't calibrate the scope or depth. Just wing it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Of course, projects might be small or large, but in every case, there is a need to develop and calibrate an appropriate scope, depth and level of your presentation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And physical formats are best for ignoring social media, ICT, gadgets entirely. Like, pretend the internet doesn't exist.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And physical formats are best for ignoring social media, I C T, gadgets entirely. Like, pretend the internet doesn't exist.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more and more people search for and find information online, it is essential to identify proper databases, apps, websites or other platforms to present and store the outcomes of your projects in cyberspace.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, and definitely skip the post-project evaluation. No celebrating with champagne or workshops—just focus on the negative and gloat about tensions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, and definitely skip the post-project evaluation. No celebrating with champagne or workshops-just focus on the negative and gloat about tensions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With your final evaluation, it is important to formally and publicly close your project by celebrating with a grand party or a formal workshop. This is not only an opportunity to open a bottle of champagne, but also to liven up the celebration with informal discussions with colleagues and friends about the highlights of the project, and to joke down possible tensions remaining after the end of the work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Dwight Eisenhower's quote about pessimism winning every battle really ties it all together, doesn't it? Even if things went well, dwell on the failures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dwight Eisenhower's quote about pessimism winning every battle really ties it all together, doesn't it? Even if things went well, dwell on the failures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pessimism never won any battle, Dwight Eisenhower famously said. Thus, even if your project faced many challenges and problems you should focus on the bright side of your experience in the project, creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So basically, do the opposite of everything they teach in project management 101. Got it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So basically, do the opposite of everything they teach in project management one hundred one. Got it.

HostA: Which is funny because it says traditional B2B presentations are paradoxically in fashion, but you still shouldn’t calibrate the scope or depth. Just wing it.

HostA: Oh, and definitely skip the post-project evaluation. No celebrating with champagne or workshops—just focus on the negative and gloat about tensions.
HostB: Dwight Eisenhower’s quote about pessimism winning every battle really ties it all together, doesn’t it? Even if things went well, dwell on the failures.
HostA: So basically, do the opposite of everything they teach in project management 101. Got it.
